metadata.case_name: Associated Hotels of India Ltd. and Mohan Singh Oberoi v. Jodha Mal Kuthalia

facts.text: By agreement dated October 2, 1947, respondent agreed to sell Nedous Hotel at Lahore to appellants for Rs. 52,75,000. Appellants paid Rs. 5,00,000 as earnest money.
Respondent's title to property defective, sale could not be completed.
Appellants filed suit in Court of Senior Subordinate Judge at Lahore for recovery of Rs. 5,10,000 (earnest + interest).
Trial court decreed suit in favour of appellant 2 for Rs. 5,08,333-5-4 with future interest at 5% p.a. Claim of appellant 1 rejected.
Respondent appealed to Lahore High Court, which allowed appeal, set aside trial decree, dismissed suit with costs.
Appellants appealed to Federal Court of Pakistan, which allowed appeal, restored trial court decree in favour of appellant 2 on December 21, 1953.
After trial decree but before Lahore HC decision, appellants executed decree; respondent obtained stay from Lahore HC on condition of depositing Rs. 3,00,000 and security for balance.
Respondent deposited Rs. 3,00,000 and furnished security.
After Lahore HC allowed respondent's appeal, respondent applied for refund of deposit; allowed on December 16, 1949, but notice to Custodian issued same day.
Custodian moved for review on December 20, 1949, claiming deposit as evacuee property vesting in him.
After Federal Court decree, respondent applied to Lahore HC (now West Pakistan HC) to apply Rs. 3,00,000 towards decree satisfaction, withdrew refund application.
Appellant 2 filed Civil Misc. Appl. No. 120/1954 praying transfer of Rs. 3,00,000 to India or payment to him, claiming not entitled to Custodian.

Lahore HC (West Pakistan) on January 20/30, 1956: Rejected transfer as amount belonged to appellant 1 (Associated Hotels Ltd.) with Muslim non-evacuee shareholders; allowed Custodian's review; directed Custodian to report evacuee interest.

Appellants applied to Punjab High Court under O.45 r.15 CPC for execution of Federal Court decree, claiming executable under s.4(3) Indian Independence Legal Proceedings Order 1947 as if passed by Supreme Court of India; alternative under s.151.
Punjab HC dismissed application on January 22, 1957: Decree under s.4(1) Order, executable by Senior Subordinate Judge Simla not HC; no non-satisfaction certificate; vested in Custodian Lahore.
Punjab HC granted certificate under Art.133(1)(a)(c) Constitution for appeal to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether the decree passed by Federal Court of Pakistan attracts s.4(1) and thus s.4(3) of Indian Independence (Legal Proceedings) Order, 1947, making it executable in India as if passed by a court of competent jurisdiction within India.

If applicable, what is the court of competent jurisdiction under s.4(3); whether O.45 r.15 CPC applies; necessity of non-satisfaction certificate under O.21 r.6(b); situs of judgment-debt and vesting in Custodian.

petitioner_arguments.text: Decree falls under s.4(1) Order as proceedings pending in Punjab civil court before appointed day; s.4(3) makes it executable in India as if by Supreme Court; O.45 r.15 applies, no need for non-satisfaction certificate; judgment-debt situs not Pakistan or not vested in Custodian.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.4 Indian Independence Legal Proceedings Order 1947; O.45 r.15 CPC

petitioner_arguments.text: Wide words 'all proceedings pending... in any civil court... in the Province of... Punjab' include this suit.

respondent_arguments.text: s.4(1) limited to proceedings where trial court jurisdiction affected by partition/territory transfer; this suit's cause of action wholly in Lahore, jurisdiction unaffected; 'effect shall be given' means recognition as foreign judgment enforceable by suit, not direct execution.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.4 Order; s.13 CPC; s.44, 44A CPC

respondent_arguments.text: No certificate under O.21 r.6(b); decree vested in Custodian Lahore under Pakistan law; O.45 r.15/s.151 inapplicable.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: O.21 r.6(b) CPC; Pakistan Evacuee Property laws

court_reasoning.text: s.4(1) applies only to pending proceedings where trial court jurisdiction affected by Act/territory transfer; here cause of action accrued wholly in Lahore jurisdiction, unaffected; thus s.4(3) inapplicable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Order made to avoid jurisdiction difficulties from partition; not all Punjab proceedings.

court_reasoning.text: s.4(3) 'effect shall be given' means executable as if by competent court in Dominion of execution.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Includes execution, not mere recognition; covers civil/criminal uniformly.

court_reasoning.text: Unnecessary to decide other issues (competent court, O.45 r.15 applicability, certificate, vesting) as s.4 inapplicable; application incompetent.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court erred on s.4 applicability but right result in dismissal.

holdings.text: s.4(1) Order applies only to proceedings where trial court jurisdiction affected by partition; present suit unaffected as cause of action in Lahore; decree not executable under s.4(3).

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal with costs, holding that the Federal Court decree does not fall under s.4 of the Indian Independence (Legal Proceedings) Order, 1947, as the original suit's jurisdiction was unaffected by partition; application under O.45 r.15 incompetent. Differed from Punjab HC on s.4 applicability but affirmed dismissal.

key_quotes.text: 's.4(1) does not apply to all proceedings pending at the material time before the specified courts but only such of them in respect of which the jurisdiction of the trial court would have been affected by the passing of the Act or by the transfer of certain territories.'
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding limiting scope of Order.

key_quotes.text: 'Effect shall be given within the territories of either of the two Dominions to any judgment, decree... as if it had been passed by a court of competent jurisdiction within that Dominion.'
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: 'The words all proceedings and in any civil or criminal court are indicative of their comprehensiveness and negative the idea of a mere change based on the territorial jurisdiction of the court.'
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Dissenting view on wide amplitude of s.4(1).
